title.narrative: Sustaining desludging of latrines and providing essential water trucking as provider of last resort to areas of need in IDP camps in 10 LGAs (Ngala, Banki, Pulka, Bama, Dikwa, Monguno, Mafa, Jere, Maiduguri, Damboa) in Borno State

description.narrative:
Through this project, UNICEF will sustain scheduled services for de-sludging of filled up latrines in formal and informal camps for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in 10 Local Government Areas (LGAs) (Ngala, Banki, Pulka, Bama, Dikwa, Monguno, Mafa, Jere, Maiduguri, Damboa) first as the implementing partner assigned specific camps in these LGAs and second as the provider of last resort, in camps where there is or there will later be no other partner providing the service. UNICEF will also provide essential water trucking services to locations in need in the capacity of provider of last resort (POLR). UNICEF has robust experience in these services having successfully implemented similar projects over the last two years, whereby UNICEF covered at least 90% of the needs for desludging latrines in IDP camps.
The two components of the project are outlined below:
a) De-sludging of latrines in IDP camps in Borno State and strengthening the faecal sludge management protocols UNICEF will procure and retain latrine desludging services from the private sector through competitive bidding leading to Long Term Agreement (LTAs) with successful bidders. In the last two years, this process of procurement has returned more competitive bids in each year, reflecting both private sector interest to provide the service in the IDP camps and high potential for linking the faecal sludge management in IDP camps to the formal faecal sludge management where it exists. The LTA contractors are deployed to de-sludge latrines in the target LGAs depending on demand and prevailing gaps for the service. The Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) as well as the WASH Sector Coordination mechanisms at both LGA and State levels coordinate the request for service.
The desludging process includes disinfection of the latrine, removal of the sludge and disposal in sites prepared under prevailing protocols approved by the Borno State Environmental Protection Agency. The IDP camps in major towns are developing as townships which can sprawl into slums if standard infrastructure for water supply and sanitation are not developed. In this respect, this project will retain capacity for faecal sludge collection, disinfection and disposal and provide a consultant to BOSEPA to review and strengthen the faecal sludge management protocols.
b) Temporary coverage for safe water through water trucking UNICEF will provide water trucking services to IDP camps or other locations experiencing gaps in safe water coverage because of disease outbreaks or arrivals of newly displaced people.
